intro: Trachyspermum gedrosiacum, commonly known as mountain cumin, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions of Central Asia and the Middle East. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic, branched stems and small, yellowish-green flowers. The plant produces oval, ridged seeds that are used in traditional medicine and as a spice due to their pungent aroma. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires minimal water, making it well adapted to harsh, dry environments. Its botanical features reflect its evolutionary adaptations to survive in extreme climatic conditions.
